channel.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
channel.description: Hey I'm trying to make a basic autotyper that will send text to the runescape client. I already have a loader and use reflection to hook enough so I can auto login. What I need to do now is send key events. This is turning out to be much less trivial then I thought. From what I can find in bcel bots they just write a keyboard class and use that to hook the keyevent manager in runescape.jar. What would be a good way for me to send input to the bot, without hacking the client?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 12:39:18 pm[/size][hr]Wait I think I was being a noob... I can just use reflection to invoke those methods... silly me.

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

oksuper_:

BAsh this is why I tend just to ignore all posts by idiots.

+1

Read full topic
item.source: How to send key events without hacking the client?

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

and you’re disappointed it didnt get more use, admit it

It would be nice to see a full bot made out of it, but I’ve come to the conclusion that if it is going to be done I will be the one doing it, no big deal.

Read full topic
item.source: How to send key events without hacking the client?

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @mikehershey mikehershey
item.description:
@mikehershey wrote:

[quote=“Kosaki, post:26, topic:303885”][quote author=mikehershey link=topic=400155.msg2968730#msg2968730 date=1253809915]

It uses significantly less for me, something to do with java+ xubuntu + the opensource api driver failage. Like drawing to screen uses 90% of a dual core 2.0, If I change the client delay to 1 second it cuts down to about 5% usage. I assume not showing the client at all would be even better[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 10:07:15 pm[/size][hr]Now that I think about it thats probably a bad assumption. Probably adding the delay to the paint method is what is freeing up so much cpu. If the client was hidden it would probably go back to using 90% of my cpu

A delay of 1sec? Thats insane. 1 FPS is terrible for a client and you should be banned very quickly.

I don’t know detectability or lack thereof, but causing a major shift of processing in the main game loop would surely raise alarms, would it not?

Potentially the client could surround its code with timers. I haven’t checked but since I haven’t seen a thread warning us about it I find it unlikely.

It would be very effective though. By moving all of the code that calls system functions you can remove most sources of delay and so benchmark graphics code against core game logic code. The only remaining uncertainty is changing system load but after a few seconds the client should have enough certainty. A bot could defeat this with a little work by benchmarking sections of code every now and again (to cope with changing system load) then replace the graphics code with waits of the appropriate (random) duration. Of course any direct modifications to the client are inherently risky.

At my school I can just change my Mac address and get assigned a new ip address. Also I play my main from a laptop with a seperate IP then I run all my ad bots on. So even if I get ip banned no big deal, I just have to run tut island solver a lot
[/quote]

Sorry to inform you but your local IP has nothing to do with your external IP seen by jagex. Yes you will be able to get a new local IP, but I highly doubt your schools router handles multiple external IPs. It is not needed in a school and therefor it is not needed to pay for it either.[/quote]
No we get public ip addresses. Each computer on our network has its own public ip address. Most colleges have a whole block like we have all of 144.118 or something.
And my only goal is to get people in my clan Idk how many accounts get banned in the process

And bash I think I meant to quote from here: (which makes what i said relevant)
Quote from: mikehershey on September 23, 2009, 10:01:42 pm
It uses significantly less for me, something to do with java+ xubuntu + the opensource api driver failage. Like drawing to screen uses 90% of a dual core 2.0, If I change the client delay to 1 second it cuts down to about 5% usage. I assume not showing the client at all would be even better

Posted on: September 23, 2009, 10:07:15 pmNow that I think about it thats probably a bad assumption. Probably adding the delay to the paint method is what is freeing up so much cpu. If the client was hidden it would probably go back to using 90% of my cpu
A delay of 1sec? Thats insane. 1 FPS is terrible for a client and you should be banned very quickly.

Read full topic

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“mikehershey, post:21, topic:303885”][quote author=BAsh link=topic=400155.msg2968601#msg2968601 date=1253791926]

It uses significantly less for me, something to do with java+ xubuntu + the opensource api driver failage. Like drawing to screen uses 90% of a dual core 2.0, If I change the client delay to 1 second it cuts down to about 5% usage. I assume not showing the client at all would be even better[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 10:07:15 pm[/size][hr]Now that I think about it thats probably a bad assumption. Probably adding the delay to the paint method is what is freeing up so much cpu. If the client was hidden it would probably go back to using 90% of my cpu

A delay of 1sec? Thats insane. 1 FPS is terrible for a client and you should be banned very quickly.

I don’t know detectability or lack thereof, but causing a major shift of processing in the main game loop would surely raise alarms, would it not?

Potentially the client could surround its code with timers. I haven’t checked but since I haven’t seen a thread warning us about it I find it unlikely.

It would be very effective though. By moving all of the code that calls system functions you can remove most sources of delay and so benchmark graphics code against core game logic code. The only remaining uncertainty is changing system load but after a few seconds the client should have enough certainty. A bot could defeat this with a little work by benchmarking sections of code every now and again (to cope with changing system load) then replace the graphics code with waits of the appropriate (random) duration. Of course any direct modifications to the client are inherently risky.
[/quote]
At my school I can just change my Mac address and get assigned a new ip address. Also I play my main from a laptop with a seperate IP then I run all my ad bots on. So even if I get ip banned no big deal, I just have to run tut island solver a lot :P[/quote]
How is this remotely relevant? I’m talking about how to prevent a bot from being detected. Not taking the boneheaded route and carrying on regardless.

item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:18, topic:303885”]Cherokee is set up with full, ready to go input classes, check out the event package:
http://cherokeeengine.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/cherokeeengine/src/com/cherokee/event/

The Keyboard class for example:
http://cherokeeengine.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/cherokeeengine/src/com/cherokee/event/keyboard/KeyBoard.java?view=markup
All it needs is a KeyListener to work, you could send it the applet for example.[/quote]

Plugplugplugplugplug

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

mikehershey:

It uses significantly less for me, something to do with java+ xubuntu + the opensource api driver failage. Like drawing to screen uses 90% of a dual core 2.0, If I change the client delay to 1 second it cuts down to about 5% usage. I assume not showing the client at all would be even better[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 10:07:15 pm[/size][hr]Now that I think about it thats probably a bad assumption. Probably adding the delay to the paint method is what is freeing up so much cpu. If the client was hidden it would probably go back to using 90% of my cpu

A delay of 1sec? Thats insane. 1 FPS is terrible for a client and you should be banned very quickly.

Taharok:

I don’t know detectability or lack thereof, but causing a major shift of processing in the main game loop would surely raise alarms, would it not?

Potentially the client could surround its code with timers. I haven’t checked but since I haven’t seen a thread warning us about it I find it unlikely.

It would be very effective though. By moving all of the code that calls system functions you can remove most sources of delay and so benchmark graphics code against core game logic code. The only remaining uncertainty is changing system load but after a few seconds the client should have enough certainty. A bot could defeat this with a little work by benchmarking sections of code every now and again (to cope with changing system load) then replace the graphics code with waits of the appropriate (random) duration. Of course any direct modifications to the client are inherently risky.

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:11, topic:303885”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=400155.msg2968497#msg2968497 date=1253764505]
It really doesn’t use a lot less cpu. The reason why it uses so much cpu isn’t just because the final 2d image is being drawn on the screen, but because of the tens of thousands of calculations done hundreds of times per second.
[/quote]

That’s why you disable the full render cycle and not just the dump at the end, surely?[/quote]

I don’t know detectability or lack thereof, but causing a major shift of processing in the main game loop would surely raise alarms, would it not?

Read full topic

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Cherokee is set up with full, ready to go input classes, check out the event package:
http://cherokeeengine.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/cherokeeengine/src/com/cherokee/event/

The Keyboard class for example:
http://cherokeeengine.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/cherokeeengine/src/com/cherokee/event/keyboard/KeyBoard.java?view=markup
All it needs is a KeyListener to work, you could send it the applet for example.

Read full topic

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @D_e_n_v_e_r D e n v e r
item.description:
@D_e_n_v_e_r wrote:

[quote=“mikehershey, post:12, topic:303885”][quote author=D e n v e r link=topic=400155.msg2968224#msg2968224 date=1253754028]

Hey I’m trying to make a basic autotyper that will send text to the runescape client. I already have a loader and use reflection to hook enough so I can auto login. What I need to do now is send key events. This is turning out to be much less trivial then I thought. From what I can find in bcel bots they just write a keyboard class and use that to hook the keyevent manager in runescape.jar. What would be a good way for me to send input to the bot, without hacking the client?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 12:39:18 pm[/size][hr]Wait I think I was being a noob… I can just use reflection to invoke those methods… silly me.

just dispatch the event from the Canvas , example:

public static void pressBackSpace(int sleep) { char c = KeyEvent.VK_BACK_SPACE; int code = (int)c; getCanvas().dispatchEvent(new KeyEvent(getCanvas(), KeyEvent.KEY_PRESSED, System.currentTimeMillis(), 0, code, c, KeyEvent.KEY_LOCATION_STANDARD)); getCanvas().dispatchEvent(new KeyEvent(getCanvas(), KeyEvent.KEY_RELEASED, System.currentTimeMillis() + sleep, 0, code, c, KeyEvent.KEY_LOCATION_STANDARD)); }
^some part of the Keyboard event dispatcher from Armsbot (my bot)

Edit: note: if you don’t know how to get the canvas, you just cast the inner component at 1,1 of the applet:

public Canvas getCanvas(){
return (Canvas)getApplet().getComponent(0).getComponentAt(1,1);
}

[/quote]
Insta-ban lets take a moment of silence for noob532_1 through noob532_4[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 10:38:14 pm[/size][hr]Wait nvm I just accidently typed one of the wrong accounts that was already banned… ignore me[/quote]
what ? its never an insta-ban , iv been testing the bot for ages, and never is an insta ban.

Edit: i’ve noticed your edit, ignore me

Read full topic
item.source: How to send key events without hacking the client?

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @mikehershey mikehershey
item.description:
@mikehershey wrote:

[quote=“D e n v e r, post:4, topic:303885”][quote author=mikehershey link=topic=400155.msg2967721#msg2967721 date=1253730924]
Hey I’m trying to make a basic autotyper that will send text to the runescape client. I already have a loader and use reflection to hook enough so I can auto login. What I need to do now is send key events. This is turning out to be much less trivial then I thought. From what I can find in bcel bots they just write a keyboard class and use that to hook the keyevent manager in runescape.jar. What would be a good way for me to send input to the bot, without hacking the client?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 12:39:18 pm[/size][hr]Wait I think I was being a noob… I can just use reflection to invoke those methods… silly me.
[/quote]
just dispatch the event from the Canvas , example:

public static void pressBackSpace(int sleep) { char c = KeyEvent.VK_BACK_SPACE; int code = (int)c; getCanvas().dispatchEvent(new KeyEvent(getCanvas(), KeyEvent.KEY_PRESSED, System.currentTimeMillis(), 0, code, c, KeyEvent.KEY_LOCATION_STANDARD)); getCanvas().dispatchEvent(new KeyEvent(getCanvas(), KeyEvent.KEY_RELEASED, System.currentTimeMillis() + sleep, 0, code, c, KeyEvent.KEY_LOCATION_STANDARD)); }
^some part of the Keyboard event dispatcher from Armsbot (my bot)

Edit: note: if you don’t know how to get the canvas, you just cast the inner component at 1,1 of the applet:

public Canvas getCanvas(){ return (Canvas)getApplet().getComponent(0).getComponentAt(1,1); } [/quote]
Insta-ban lets take a moment of silence for noob532_1 through noob532_4[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 10:38:14 pm[/size][hr]Wait nvm I just accidently typed one of the wrong accounts that was already banned… ignore me

item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Taharok:

It really doesn’t use a lot less cpu. The reason why it uses so much cpu isn’t just because the final 2d image is being drawn on the screen, but because of the tens of thousands of calculations done hundreds of times per second.

That’s why you disable the full render cycle and not just the dump at the end, surely?

item.title: How to send key events without hacking the client?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

mikehershey:

Hmm but theroetically I could make a “hero_merch” (shamelessly promotes my merch clan) ad bot that didnt even have a client visible if I invoked the actually runescape functions, and would much less of my cpu so i could bot many more accounts at one time. Is it possible to send input to something that isn’t visible?

It really doesn’t use a lot less cpu. The reason why it uses so much cpu isn’t just because the final 2d image is being drawn on the screen, but because of the tens of thousands of calculations done hundreds of times per second.

Read full topic
